skill.name: pymc-bayesian-modeling
skill.description: Bayesian modeling with PyMC. Build hierarchical models, MCMC (NUTS), variational inference, LOO/WAIC comparison, posterior checks, for probabilistic programming and inference.
skill.summary: Bayesian modeling with PyMC. Build hierarchical models, MCMC (NUTS), variational inference, LOO/WAIC...
skill.author: K-Dense-AI

security_audit.summary: All 383 static findings are false positives. The 'weak cryptographic algorithm' detections flag legitimate PyMC probability distributions. The 'external_commands' findings flag markdown backtick syntax. This is a legitimate scientific computing skill for Bayesian statistical modeling.

content.value_statement: Build, fit, and validate Bayesian models using PyMC. Create hierarchical models, run MCMC sampling, and compare models with LOO and WAIC metrics.
actual_capabilities: Build Bayesian models including linear regression, logistic regression, and hierarchical multilevel models
Perform MCMC sampling using the NUTS algorithm with automatic tuning
Run prior and posterior predictive checks for model validation
Compare multiple models using LOO and WAIC information criteria
Diagnose sampling convergence with R-hat, ESS, and divergence checks
Generate predictions with uncertainty quantification using posterior distributions
limitations: Requires familiarity with Bayesian statistics and probability distributions
Does not include automatic model selection or feature engineering
Does not provide pre-trained models or transfer learning capabilities
Large hierarchical models may require significant computational resources

use_cases.title: Uncertainty Quantification
use_cases.description: Quantify uncertainty in regression coefficients and predictions using full posterior distributions.

use_cases.title: Hierarchical Data Analysis
use_cases.description: Analyze grouped or nested data structures with partial pooling across groups.

use_cases.title: Model Comparison
use_cases.description: Compare competing statistical models using LOO cross-validation and model weights.

prompt_templates.title: Simple Linear Regression
prompt_templates.prompt: Build a Bayesian linear regression model using PyMC with the following predictors and outcome variable. Include prior predictive checks, sample the posterior using NUTS, and check convergence diagnostics.

prompt_templates.title: Hierarchical Model
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a hierarchical Bayesian model for data with group structure. Use non-centered parameterization to avoid sampling issues. Show group-level estimates and shrinkage toward the population mean.

prompt_templates.title: Model Comparison
prompt_templates.prompt: Fit two or more Bayesian models to the same data and compare them using LOO. Report the model weights and provide interpretation guidelines for the comparison results.

prompt_templates.title: Full Workflow
prompt_templates.prompt: Run a complete Bayesian analysis workflow including data preparation, model building, prior predictive checks, MCMC sampling with 4 chains, convergence diagnostics, posterior predictive checks, and predictions for new data.

output_examples.input: Build a Bayesian linear regression with predictors X1, X2 and outcome y
output: Model: alpha ~ Normal(0,1), beta ~ Normal(0,1), sigma ~ HalfNormal(1)
R-hat values all below 1.01 indicating convergence
Posterior predictive checks showing model fit

output_examples.input: Create a hierarchical model with 10 groups and 50 observations each
output: Population-level hyperparameters: mu_alpha, sigma_alpha, mu_beta, sigma_beta
Group-level parameters showing shrinkage toward population mean
Comparison of group intercepts with forest plot

output_examples.input: Compare three model specifications using LOO
output: LOO comparison table with rank, elpd_loo, and weights
Recommendation for best model with interpretation
Model-averaged predictions if models are similar

best_practices: Standardize predictors before modeling to improve sampling efficiency
Use weakly informative priors rather than flat priors for better inference
Always run prior predictive checks before fitting to validate priors
Check convergence diagnostics (R-hat < 1.01, ESS > 400, no divergences) before interpreting results
anti_patterns: Using flat priors (Uniform(0, 1e10)) instead of informative priors
Interpreting results without checking convergence diagnostics
Using centered parameterization for hierarchical models (causes divergences)
Fitting complex models without prior predictive checks

faq.question: What is PyMC?
faq.answer: PyMC is a Python library for probabilistic programming that enables Bayesian modeling and Markov Chain Monte Carlo sampling.

faq.question: What is MCMC sampling?
faq.answer: MCMC (Markov Chain Monte Carlo) is a family of algorithms that generate samples from a probability distribution when direct sampling is difficult.

faq.question: What is the NUTS algorithm?
faq.answer: NUTS (No-U-Turn Sampler) is an adaptive Hamiltonian Monte Carlo algorithm that automatically tunes step size and trajectory length.

faq.question: What are priors in Bayesian analysis?
faq.answer: Priors represent knowledge or beliefs about parameters before observing data. They are combined with data through Bayes theorem to produce posteriors.

faq.question: What is R-hat?
faq.answer: R-hat (Gelman-Rubin statistic) measures convergence across chains. Values below 1.01 indicate good convergence.

faq.question: When should I use hierarchical models?
faq.answer: Use hierarchical models when data has grouped or nested structure, allowing partial pooling of information across groups.
